data.text: Family homes included Beechwood in Elmete Lane and Carr Head in West Avenue, Roundhay; Mount Pleasant in Harehills; Newton Hall, Chapeltown;  North Town End, Potternewton Hall; Rockland, Chapeltown; Springwood,Oakwood Lane; and The Acacia in Oakwood Garden, Leeds.

Hugh Lupton, Francis III's fifth son, hosted visits by the Princess Royal and her husband Lord Harewood, in his role as Lord Mayor of Leeds, with his wife Isabella Simey as Lady Mayoress. https://t.co/QRkYo2Gvxw

Sir Charles Lupton OBE, Francis III's 4th son, was a member of the Court and Council of the University and chairman of the Law Committee; the Lord Mayor of Leeds; the Deputy-Lieutenant for the West Riding of Yorkshire; the city council's Chairman of the Improvements Committee; https://t.co/kT6PlX0abL

Francis Lupton III (1813–1884) joined the board of the Bank of Leeds, became a magistrate of the West Riding of Yorkshire and overseer of the poor in the parish of Roundhay. He was chairman of the finance committee of the Yorkshire College of Science, created in 1874.

Francis Martineau Lupton's younger daughter, Anne, attended Newnham College at Cambridge University. Anne had wished to enter the family business, but as women were excluded, she traveled for many years in South America and Canada in  particular. https://t.co/YxlihmPVB6

The Lupton Residences of the University of Leeds are named after members of the family, and the law firm established by solicitor Sir Charles Lupton as Dibb-Lupton which after a merger became DLA Piper.
